metadata.title: Utilization of leached MnO2 for the mechanosynthesis of nano LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3_ Sinterability and properties

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ceramics International
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ceramint
Utilization of leached MnO2 for the mechanosynthesis of nano LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3: Sinterability and properties
Rehab E.A. Ngidaa, M.F. Zawraha,∗, R.M. Khattaba, E. Heikalb
aNational Research Centre, Refractories, Ceramics and Building Materials Department, 12622, Dokki, Cairo, Egypt bAin Shams University, Faculty of Science, Chemistry Department, 11566, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Leaching Synthesis Manganite Mechanical activation Physical properties Electrical and magnetic properties
A B S T R A C T
The present study focuses on the leaching of MnO2 form manganese ore by acid leaching method using glucose as a reducing agent. The leached MnO2 was used to prepare nano LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 (x=0.1, 0.3, 0.5 and 1) perovskites by mechanical activation method in the presence of La2O3, CaO or SrO. The leached MnO2 and synthesized perovskite powders were investigated by x-ray diffraction technique (XRD) and transmission electron microscope (TEM).The prepared LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 perovskites were subjected for sintering up to 1350 and 1400 °C, respectively. The physical, electrical and magnetic properties as well as microstructure of sintered perovskites were investigated. The results showed that MnO2 was successfully leached and utilized for preparation of nano LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 perovskites after milling for 8 h. LaxCa(1x)MnO3 was sintered at 1350 °C while LaxSr(1-x)MnO3 was sintered 1400 °C. The doping with Ca and Sr led to decreasing the electrical resistivity, while they led improving the magnetic property until specific limit (x= 0.5) after which magnetic property was decreased again with increasing their amounts. The highest magnetization was obtained for La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3. In all cases, their values were higher than that of pure LaMnO3.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, a great consideration has been taken and focused to find extremely competent electronic materials for cooling applications [1–3], as well as magnetic and power generations [4–6]. As published in literatures, several electronic materials such as NaCoO2 [7], Sr1−xLaxTiO3 [8], Ca0.8Dy0.2MnO3 [9] or Nd1−xCaxCoO3 [10] have been prepared and exhibited significant electrical and thermal properties. Nowadays, nanostructure perovskite-manganites doped with metals have showed a large attention due to their non-toxicity, chemicalstability and low-production cost with opportunity of being applied at high temperature. They have the general formula LnxA1-xMnO3, where Ln is a trivalent rare-earth metal as La, Ce, Nd, Gd, Sm and A is a divalent alkaline earth metal as Ca, Sr, Ba, and Pb. The electrical properties of perosvkite-type oxides are related to their stoichiometry and composition. A significant variation has been detected when the degree of replacement for La with alkali-earth element is varied from 0.0 to 50% [8]. Manganites exhibit a transition from paramagnetic to ferromagnetic states [11-12], i.e. insulator-metal transition is happened after substitution of Ln with divalent alkaline-earth due to the formation of mixed Mn3+/Mn4+ ions. The common methods employed for
preparation of LaxA1-xMnO3 micro- or nano-particles are solid state reaction, sol-gel and co-precipitation [13]. These techniques have some drawbacks, for example; the solid-state method requires high sintering temperature ranged from 1250 to 1400 K with soaking time>12 h to obtain homogenous stoichiometric composition with suitable grain size and porosity. Also, the sol-gel method requires a complicated chemical steps with sensitive conditions. It is a higher cost technique with low yield [14]. Recently, mechanical-activation or mechanical-milling has been reported as a new method for preparing of perovskite manganites by mixing of manganese oxides, alkaline-earths and rare-earth oxides [15–17]. This procedure depends mainly on mechanical activation of raw mixture by high energy ball milling to induce chemical reactions between the component reactants. The advantages of this method are including high yield (preferable for industry), low-cost, low temperature synthesis and the effectiveness for synthesis of nanoparticles oxides [18–28].
Naturally, manganese present as pyrolusite (MnO2) which is stable in alkaline and acidic media. So, the recovering of manganese from its source has to be occurred under suitable reducing conditions [29–31]. In traditional technologies, coal can be used as reducing agent in the presence of sulfuric acid to produce manganese oxide, but this method
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2019.10.056 Received 17 September 2019; Received in revised form 6 October 2019; Accepted 7 October 2019
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: mzawrah@hotmail.com (M.F. Zawrah).
Ceramics International xxx (xxxx) xxx–xxx
0272-8842/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: Rehab E.A. Ngida, et al., Ceramics International, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2019.10.056
produces smoke, oxy-sulfide, dust and nitrogen oxides that greatly pollute the environment. Also, this method requires high reaction temperature [32]. Various reducing agents as pyrite, aqueous sulfur dioxide, and hydrogen peroxide have been used conventionally under different acidic media but they might be harmful. So, many studies have been focused on using organic reducing agents, mainly carbohydrates such as oxalic acid, methanol, sucrose and lactose [33–38]. These methods were efficient and simple under mild conditions i.e. temperature (< 80 °C) [39]. Belyi et al., (2006), used sulfuric acid approach for leaching of manganese ore under varying reaction conditions [40]. Ismail et al. (2004) studied the leaching of low grade manganese ores using either sawdust or lactose as effective reducing agents in acid medium [41] with successful results.
The present study focuses on leaching of nano MnO2 for the Egyptian manganese ore. Afterward, the production of LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 (x=0.1- 0.3- 0.5 and 1) perovskites nano particles using the leached MnO2 is also the main goal of the current work. The proposed perovskites are prepared by mechanical activation technique of relevant oxides followed by sintering at different temperatures. Investigation of prepared powders and sintered bodies is also aimed in the present study.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The reactant oxides; La2O3 (99.9%), SrO, CaO (> 99%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, while MnO2 was chemically recovered by acid leaching method from pyrolusite manganese ore (Sinai-Om Bogma area) using glucose as a reducing agent in HNO3. XRF analysis of manganese ore is illustrated in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Leaching of pure manganese oxide from manganese ore
sections.text:
The extraction of manganese oxide from manganese ore was carried out under reducing conditions. Typically, 10 g manganese ore was firstly crushed and powdered to obtain suitable particle size. Then, the powder was putted in a closed glass flask with 2 g glucose as a reducing agent, and 120ml of 2.7M HNO3, as represented in equation (1). The leaching experiments were kept on hot plate under stirring (200 rpm) at 90 °C for 4 h. After that, the suspension was subjected for filtration to separate the insoluble residue. Iron was precipitated by diluted ammonium hydroxide while the manganese was precipitated by diluted NaOH. Then, the powder was activated by nitric acid to produce MnO2. The final MnO2 powder was dried and passed on magnet to remove any traces of iron, then utilized for manganite preparation [17,42]. The flow chart of preparation method is shown in Fig. 1.
C6H12O6+12MnO2+24H+=6CO2+12Mn2++18H2O (1)

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 nanostructures
sections.text: LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 (x=0.1, 0. 3, 0.7 and 1.0) perovskites were prepared by milling of La2O3, CaO, and SrO pure chemicals with MnO2 extracted from manganese ore in a planetary ball mill type SFM-1Desk-Top. The powder/ball weight ratio was 1:10 and the rotating speed was adjusted at 400 rpm for 8 h to obtain nano powders [15-16]. The prepared powders were calcined at 900 and 1100 °C and examined by X-ray diffraction technique type Philips PW 137; XRD machine with CuK- Ni filtered radiation, and transmission electron microscope type JEOL JEM-1230 as well as selected area electron diffraction (SAED). Moreover, the prepared powder was pressed to form compacted pellets, then sintered at 1250, 1350 and 1400 °C. X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscope type SEM Philips XL30 were used to identify the perosvkite phases and microstructure of sintered bodies, respectively. The density and apparent porosity of sintered specimens were determined by Archimedes water displacement method. The electrical and magnetic properties of the prepared samples were estimated by broadband dielectric spectrometer (BDS) and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM model 7041.

sections.heading: 3.1. Composition manganese ore and extracted MnO2
sections.text: Table 1 illustrates the mineralogical composition of manganese ore as examined by XRF technique. From the Table, it is indicated that the ore composes mainly of Mn and Fe oxides with few amount of SiO2 and trace amounts of other oxides. On the other hand, Fig. 2 depicts XRD of manganese ore. It is appeared that the ore constitutes of different elements in form of Clinochlore (Mg11.148 Fe0.852) ((Si4.99 Al3.01)O20(O H)16) and Bixbyite (Fe0.42 Mn0.58)2O3. Fig. 3 shows XRD patterns of MnO2 powder after being extracted and dried at 200 °C. All characteristic peaks of MnO2 are detected in the pattern indicating the success of proposed method of preparation. The extracted MnO2 was used to prepare perovskite manganites by mechanical activation method.

sections.heading: 3.2. Composition and morphology of prepared perovskite manganites
3.2.1. Phase composition of La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 and La0.1Sr0.9MnO3
sections.text:
To follow the phase composition of prepared perovskite powders,
two samples, namely; La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 and La0.1Sr0.9MnO3, were selected and examined by XRD technique after calcination at 900 and 1100 °C as shown in Figs. 4 and 5. As indicated in Fig. 4, broad peaks are detected indicating the formation low crystalline La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 perovskite after calcination at 900 °C. Furthermore, trace amount of La2O3 could be identified in the pattern. It has been reported in previous published work [43] that La01Ca0.9MnO3 perovskite phase was formed with trace amount of La2O3 when prepared at 240 °C for 48 h. The formation of La2O3 indicating the incompletion of reaction. After calcination at 1100 °C, well crystalline La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 perovskite phase is completely formed since the detected peaks are sharp and intense. The trace amount of La2O3 is disappeared after calcination at 1100 °C indicating the completion of reaction. The behavior of phase formation is the same in case of La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 as shown in Fig. 5. Small amount of La2O3 is formed in addition to the main La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 perovskite phase when calcined at 900 °C while it disappeared after calcination at 1100 °C with the formation of well crystalline La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 phase.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Morphology of prepared La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 and La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 powders
sections.text:
Figs. 6 and 7 show TEM images with selected area electron
Fig. 1. Flow chart for preparation of activated and non-activated manganese products.
Fig. 2. XRD pattern of manganese ore.
diffractions (SAED) of prepared La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 and La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 powders calcined at 900 °C, respectively. It can be seen that the diameter of single La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 and La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 particles is about 15 nm. The particles tend to agglomerate due to their small sizes. La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 is highly agglomerated than La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 perovskite. From TEM images and diffraction pattern, a crystalline nature of powder is confirmed where nanostructures with well-controlled dimensions, uniform sizes, phase purity and homogenous chemical compositions are detected.
3.2.3. Phase identification of sintered perovskites Fig. 8 shows XRD patterns of LaMnO3, La0.1Ca0.9MnO3, La0.3Ca0.7MnO3 and La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 pervoskites sintered at 1350 °C. The peaks of crystalline LaMnO3, La0.1Ca0.9MnO3, La0.3Ca0.7MnO3 and La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 phases are detected in the patterns. With increasing of the calcium content, the peaks are shifted to lower 2θ values. This
means that the unit cell volume increases gradually with decreasing of the calcium percentage. This is attributed to the differences between the ionic radii of Mn4+ and Mn3+ and size variances between the La3+ and Ca2+. Mn4+ is formed due to the replacement of Ca or Sr to keep the neutrality of the system with the formation of oxygen vacancies.
Fig. 9 displays XRD patterns of LaMnO3, La0.1Sr0.9MnO3, La0.3Sr0.7MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 pervoskites sintered at 1350 °C. The characteristic peaks of LaMnO3, La0.1Sr0.9MnO3, La0.3Sr0.7MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 are appeared in the patterns. After firing at 1350 °C, the peaks of trace LaMnO3 are disappeared and well crystalline singlephase perovskite structure is detected. The peaks of perovskite phases are slightly shifted to lower 2θ values, indicating the fractional substitution of La by Sr. The systematic shift in the peaks position of perovskites is owing to differences between the ionic radii of Mn4+ and Mn3+, the size differences between the La3+ and Sr2+ ions and their
Fig. 3. XRD patterns of extracted MnO2 from manganese ore.
concentration in the unit cell. It has been described that when Ca2+ is doped at the expanse of La3+site in La-based materials; the crystalstructure is probable to be orthorhombic, while when it is doped with Sr2+, the material is probable to be converted into rhombohedral perovskite and in all case in single phase is formed [13,44,45].

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Physical properties of sintered perovskites
sections.text:
The perovskite manganite-materials are ceramic in nature.
Consequently, porosity and density are the utmost significant parameters which determine the whole properties of sintered manganites. Thus, to develop and increase the mechanical properties of ceramic materials, it is necessary to recognize the relationship between porosity and bulk density. Fig. 10 shows apparent porosity and bulk density of LaMnO3, La0.1Ca0.9MnO3, La0.3Ca0.7MnO3 and La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 perovskites sintered at 1100, 1250 and 1350 °C. As indicated in the figure, the porosity decreases with increasing the temperature up to 1350 °C. Also, it increases with increasing the concentration of calcium. It is worth mentioning that the samples were deformed when the sintering was conducted at higher than 1350 °C. At 1350 °C, their values are in the range between 6-12%. On the other side, the bulk density goes in an opposite trend of the apparent porosity. The reduction of porosity with rising the temperature is attributed to grain-grain interaction with the possibility of liquid phases' formation that produced from the low melting materials. At the same temperature, the density of LaMnO3 is higher than La0.1Ca0.9MnO3, La0.3Ca0.7MnO3 and La0.5Ca0.5MnO3. This is attributed to the higher theoretical density of LaMnO3 (6.52 g/cm3)
in comparison with that of CaMnO3 (4.58 g/cm3). The substitution of La (ionic radius 1.032 Å) by Ca (1.00 Å) leads to decreasing the lattice parameters with shrinkage of the lattice and formation of smaller unit cell. Also, the replacement of La by Ca tends to conversion of Mn+3 ion (ionic radii, 0.645 Å) into Mn+4(ionic radii, 0.53 Å) with formation of one mobile hole [14] which consequently helps in reduction of unit cell size and density. Fig. 11 depicts apparent porosity and bulk density of LaMnO3, La0.1Sr0.9MnO3, La0.3Sr0.7MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 perovskites sintered at 1250, 1350 and 1400 °C. In this case, the behavior is similar for that of calcium-containing perovskites except the sintering temperature is reached to 1400 °C. This means that strontium-containing perovskites need higher sintering temperature than calciumcontaining perovskites due to the higher melting temperature of SrMnO3 (1740 °C) than CaMnO3 (1500 °C). At the 1350 °C, the values of density are higher for calcium-containing perovskites than strontiumcontaining perovskites in spite of the lesser theoretical density of CaMnO3 (4.58 g/cm3) than that of SrMnO3 (5.42 g/cm3).

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Microstructure of sintered perovskites
sections.text:
SEM images of LaMnO3, La0.1Ca0.9MnO3, La0.3Ca0.7MnO3 and La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 perovskites sintered at 1350 °C are shown in Fig. 12, whileas SEM images LaMnO3, La0.1Sr0.9MnO3, La0.3Sr0.7MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 perovskites sintered at 1400 °C are shown in Fig. 13. Generally, the microstructure features (grain shapes, grain sizes, homogeneity, grain boundary interaction and porosity) are totally different for all sintered perovskite compositions. The microstructure of
Fig. 6. TEM images (a) and selected area electron diffraction (b) of La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 annealed at 900 °C.
sintered LaMnO3 (Figs. 12a and Fig. 13a) exhibits rode-like grains with average length of 3-4 μm and aspect ratio of about 3.5. It also displays homogenous and relatively dense microstructure with some pores and minor unknown phases. For La0.1Ca0.9MnO3 perovskite (Fig. 12b), heterogeneous grain size and homogeneous grain shapes (euhedral) with well contacted grain boundaries are detected in the microstructure. The size of grain ranges between> 1-5 μm. For La0.3Ca0.7MnO3 perovskite (Fig. 12c), it exhibits the most regular grain shape and size with homogenous pore distribution among the other perovskites. All grains are spherical with size ranges between>11.5 μm. In case of La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 perovskite (Fig. 12d), in comparison with the other perovskites, coarse grains are formed; their sizes-range is between 5-15 μm. The grains are edged with different shapes like cubes, prisms, rectangles and cuboids. Moreover, the pores are homogenously distributed in the microstructure. On the other hand, the microstructures of La0.1Sr0.9MnO3 and La0.3Sr0.7MnO3 sintered at 1400 °C are relatively similar. They exhibit very small crystalline grains with the presence of some fused-like grains; the grain size is less than 1 μm. Pores having different sizes are appeared and homogenously distributed in the microstructure. For La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 perovskite, coarse grains with size of about 1-5 μm are formed; most of them are spherical in shape with the presence of cubic and octahedron grains. The size of spherical
Fig. 8. XRD patterns of LaxCa1-xMnO3 sintered at 1350 °C.
grains is lower than the cubic and octahedron grains.

sections.heading: 3.2.6. Electrical resistivity of sintered perovskites
sections.text:
The electrical resistance property is one of the greatest methods to
investigate the electrical properties of materials like perovskites. The effect of Ca and Sr doping on the electrical properties of LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxCa1-xMnO3 perovskites, where (x= 0.1, 0.3, 0.5 and 1), sintered at 1350 °C and 1400 °C are shown in Figs. 14 and 15, respectively. It is indicated that the electrical resistivity of LaMnO3 is higher than both LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxCa1-xMnO3 perovskites. It also decreases with the increase of Ca or Sr amounts in the perovskites. Moreover, the perovskites that contain Ca exhibit higher resistivity than those contain Sr. LaMnO3 is an intrinsic p-type semiconductor having relatively high resistivity. When La3+ ion is replaced by lower oxidation sate metalions like Sr2+ or Ca2+, this leads to increasing the oxidation state of Mn3+ ion [46] in B-site or generating of an electron-hole in the same site. This is to preserve electro neutrality situation. The probable equations are described as follows:
+ → −
+ +
− + +LaMnO xCaO La Ca Mn Mn O3 1 x3 x 2 x 1 3 x 4 3
+ + + → + + +Mn O 2CaO 0.5O (g) LaMnO 2Ca‵ 2Mn 6O 2ḣ2 3 2 3 La Mnx ox
After replacement, Mn3+ is reacted with an electron hole to produce Mn4+ cation (Mn3++h•→Mn4+) leading to decreasing the electrical resistivity of La(Ca, or Sr)MnO3. Furthermore, charge neutrality might be produced via oxygen-vacancy. The potential equation can express as follows:
+ + → + + +2CaO Mn O LaMnO 2Ca‵ 2Mn 6O V2 3 3 La Mnx ox o··
In case of reduction for two Mn4+ cations into Mn3+ cation, an oxygen vacancy is generated and O2− conduction happens. With increasing of Ca percentage at La-site, more electron hole and oxygen vacancy are generated leading to decreasing the resistivity. The differences in the size of Ca (ionic radius 1.18 Å) and Sr (ionic radius 1.31 Å) might lead to different electrical resistivity [47].
Fig. 11. Apparent porosity and bulk density of LaxSr(1-x)MnO3 sintered at 1250, 1350 and 1400 °C.
Fig. 13. SEM images of (a) LaMnO3, (b) La0.1Sr0.9MnO3, (c) La0.3Sr0.7MnO3, (d) La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 sintered at 1400 °C.
Fig. 14. Electrical resistivity of LaxCa(1-x)MnO3 pervoskites sintered at 1350 °C.

sections.heading: 3.2.7. Magnetic properties of sintered perovskites
sections.text:
The relationship between in magnetization and magnetic field of
prepared LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxCa1-xMnO3 perovskites, (x= 0.1, 0.3, 0.5 and 1) are shown in Figs. 16 and 17. It is clear that magnetization of perovskites doped with Ca and Sr are higher than that of pure LaMnO3. Also, the optimum magnetization is obtained when the value of Ca or Sr is x= 0.5 (i.e. La0.5Sr0.5MnO3 and La0.5Ca0.5MnO3). When the amounts of Ca or Sr are increased into 0.7 and 0.9, the magnetization is decreased again. The magnetic behavior of prepared perovskite phases is primarily affected by the variation of Mn4+ content which is controlled by neutrality mechanism (La3++Mn3+/O2−/A2++Mn4+), i.e. it depends on double exchange mechanism between Mn3+ and Mn4+ which induced due to substitution of divalent cations, and consequently depends on the mobility of eg electrons and the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+. Also, the applied magnetic-field makes delocalization of charge carriers, which in turn destroys the resistivity producing local arrangement of the magnetic spins. Owing to this ordering, the ferromagnetic-metallic state might destroy the paramagnetic insulating regime causing complete polarization of conduction electrons (e1g) inside the magnetic-domains and being easily transferred between Mn3+ and Mn4+
via oxygen that introducing holes into the this material. The holes permit charge-transfer in the eg state which is greatly hybridized with the oxygen-2p-state. The produced oxygen deficiency and holes in the lattice form oxygen-vacant superstructure which lead to domination of super exchange interaction between Mn3+–O–Mn3+ leading to the enhancement of ferromagnetic properties [48]. The perovskites that contain Sr have higher magnetization than LaMnO3 and perovskites that contain Ca, this because the Ca ion has asmaller size than Sr ion. As the strontium content cause the gradual straightening of the Mn–O–Mn angle that influences the magnetic interactions between manganese neighbors and decrease the structural distortion.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
⁃ Highly pure manganese oxide was successfully prepared by acid leaching method from relatively low grade Sinai manganese ore using glucose as a reducing agent
⁃ Nano LaMnO3, LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 (x= 0.1, 0.3, 0.5 and 1) perovskites were also successfully prepared by mechanical milling for 8 h of leached-manganese oxide with pure oxide precursors (La2O3, CaO or SrO) and calcination at 900 or 1100 °C ⁃ The optimal sintering temperature was 1350 °C for LaxCa(1-x)MnO3 while it was 1400 °C for LaxSr(1-x)MnO3. These sintering temperatures could affect the microstructure and suitable for giving improved physical properties
⁃ The electrical resistivity was found to depend on the amount of doped Ca or Sr. The electrical resistivity decreased with increasing Ca or Sr content. On the other hand, the magnetization was increased with increasing the amount of Ca or Sr until specific limit (x= 0.5), then decreased with increasing their values. The highest magnetization was obtained for La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3. The lower magnetic property was achieved for pure LaMnO3.

metadata.abstractText: The present study focuses on the leaching of MnO2 form manganese ore by acid leaching method using glucose as a reducing agent. The leached MnO2 was used to prepare nano LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 (x=0.1, 0.3, 0.5 and 1) perovskites by mechanical activation method in the presence of La2O3, CaO or SrO. The leached MnO2 and synthesized perovskite powders were investigated by x-ray diffraction technique (XRD) and transmission electron microscope (TEM).The prepared LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 perovskites were subjected for sintering up to 1350 and 1400 °C, respectively. The physical, electrical and magnetic properties as well as microstructure of sintered perovskites were investigated. The results showed that MnO2 was successfully leached and utilized for preparation of nano LaxCa1-xMnO3 and LaxSr1-xMnO3 perovskites after milling for 8 h. LaxCa(1x)MnO3 was sintered at 1350 °C while LaxSr(1-x)MnO3 was sintered 1400 °C. The doping with Ca and Sr led to decreasing the electrical resistivity, while they led improving the magnetic property until specific limit (x= 0.5) after which magnetic property was decreased again with increasing their amounts. The highest magnetization was obtained for La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 and La0.5Sr0.5MnO3. In all cases, their values were higher than that of pure LaMnO3.
